modules.module_title: The Author's Aspiration and Early Conflict

content.context: After understanding ancient (Vedic) scriptures out of his own volition, the author wished for the Earth to be a certain way and found the following utterance within himself:

content.title: Upbringing and Early Dissatisfaction
content.text: The author's journey began in a hard-working, pious, and venerated family in the Vedic tradition. He started by following the path shown by his parents and teachers, but from the beginning, he was dissatisfied with the dogmas and sanctions of the tradition, such as rules like "do this - don’t do that".

content.title: The First Cause of Misery
content.text: This dissatisfaction led to his elders becoming unhappy with his attitude. This became the first cause of his misery, as he struggled between trying to make them happy and judging them against their own standards.

modules.module_title: Deepening Conflict and the Turn to Vedanta

content.title: The Crux Point and a Sacred Oath
content.text: The author realized that his revered and scholarly elders were not happy all the time, which became a crux point for him. This led him to take a 'sacred oath' to never blindly follow the dictates of tradition, a resolve that grew stronger as his elders failed to convince him with their reasoning.

content.title: The Second Cause of Misery
content.text: As his rejection of tradition grew, his elders began to worry that he was obstinately negating their beliefs without having studied the scriptures. Their worry and disapproval became the second cause of his misery.

content.title: The Three Sections of the Vedic Path

items.details: The first section, which describes actions (karma) that, according to the Vedas, lead one to heaven.
The second section, describing the rituals and ceremonies for becoming gods and goddesses.
The third section, which states that knowledge alone is supreme.

content.title: The Riddle of Knowledge
content.text: When the author asked what this supreme knowledge was, the answer was 'knowledge of Brahman'. When he asked what Brahman was, he was told it was beyond his comprehension and that the only way to realize it was to adhere to the dictates and sanctions in the scriptures.

modules.module_title: The Paradox of Vedanta and the Path to Samadhi

content.title: The Promise of Samadhi
content.text: The author's elders assured him that realization of Brahman and answers to all his questions would happen in the state of Samadhi, a deep meditative state.

content.title: Core Philosophical Questions
items: What is bondage and what is salvation?
If salvation is the dissolution of the self (atma) into the Supreme Self (Brahman), why did Brahman place itself into living beings (jeevas) in the first place?

content.title: A Pointless Argument
content.text: His elders dismissed his persistent questioning as a pointless argument because he wouldn't blindly accept their dictates. They again insisted the answers would be found in samadhi.

modules.module_title: National Disappointment and the Journey to Amarkantak

content.title: Disappointment in National Character
content.text: Alongside his spiritual quest, the author was pained by changes he saw in leaders after Indian Independence in 1947. By 1950, he concluded that the new Constitution failed to describe the character of a 'right human being' or a national character.

content.title: The Final Attempt
content.text: Having exhausted other avenues, he and his wife decided to make one last attempt to find answers in samadhi and traveled to the sacred place of Amarkantak in 1950.

He began the agam-tantra-upasana method, a practice prescribed in scriptures for attaining samadhi. It involves visualizing gods and goddesses in parts of one's own body (an activity called 'nyas'), based on the formula 'Becoming God, worship Godhead'.

modules.module_title: The Experience of Samadhi and a New Path

content.title: Achieving a State of Pure Awareness
content.text: After dedicated practice, the author one day became free from the imagined gods and goddesses, left only with the awareness 'I am'. In this state, he had no sense of time, place, body, or thought for several hours, which he believed to be samadhi.

content.title: The Second Failure
content.text: Despite achieving this state daily for a year, no answers to his questions came. He considered this his second major failure, after not finding answers in Vedanta, and felt he was at a deadlock.

content.title: The Problem of Evidence
content.text: He then realized a new problem: there was nothing in this state that could be described, so he had no way to testify or present evidence of his experience to the world.

content.title: The Turn to Sanyam
content.text: To overcome this difficulty and test his achievement, he decided to perform 'sanyam', a method mentioned in the Patanjali Yoga Sutra.

modules.module_title: The Method of Sanyam and the Discovery of Jeevan

content.title: Improvising on Sanyam
content.text: The author found the traditional method of 'sanyam' to be unacceptable and improvised by reversing the prescribed order. As a result, he began to see and understand every bit of existence.
In this state, he discovered the 'jeevan atom', the conscious self that is the same in every being and uses the body as an instrument to evidence its presence.

content.title: The Three Stages of Jeevan's Desire
items: Jeevan first wants to live, a stage achieved in the animal world.
Thereafter, it wants to become happy.
Finally, it wants to produce evidences of being happy.

content.title: The Formula for Happiness
content.text: He discovered the formula for human happiness is 'Living in the Universal Order'.

modules.module_title: The Order of Existence and the Role of Wisdom

items.details: All material world in solid, liquid, and gaseous states.
All organisms composed of bio-cells, based on chemical substances and fluids.

content.title: The Uniqueness of the Human Body
content.text: The key difference in the human body is the 'fully enriched brain', which allows jeevan to express itself in a multi-dimensional way.

content.title: The Path to Human Happiness
content.text: Human happiness is possible by living according to the specific definition and order of human beings, which requires achieving wisdom.

content.title: A Note on Sadhana (Spiritual Practice)
content.text: The author testifies that experiencing stray thoughts during sadhana is a normal difficulty faced by all aspirants before achieving samadhi.

modules.module_title: The Nature of Bondage and the Definition of Humanness

content.text: Bondage is ignorance or illusion, specifically, a human living like an animal. Salvation is to be liberated from this illusion.

content.title: Critique of Present Education
content.text: Modern education perpetuates this ignorance through its content of 'sex-obsessed psychology, consumption-obsessed sociology, and profit-obsessed economics'.
Humanness is the work and behavior of an awakened human being. Describing this becomes the basis for a Constitution for all humanity.

modules.module_title: The Nature of Salvation and Existence

content.title: Salvation as Liberation
content.text: Salvation is not about miracles but about being liberated from illusion, which can happen instantly, nullifying all past mistakes.

content.context: A discovered formula regarding human agreement:
lines: We humans are one in right and many in wrong.

items.details: The first reality, consisting of things which could be counted.
The second reality, which pervades everywhere and in which every unit of nature is submerged.

content.title: Categories within Nature
content.text: Nature has two categories: the insentient world (material and bio orders) and the sentient world (animal-kind and humankind).

modules.module_title: The Emergence of 'Madhyasth Darshan'

content.title: Five States of Being Achieved Through Wisdom
The Four Chapters of Madhyasth Darshan

items.details: Holistic view of Human Behaviour.
Holistic view of Human Actions.
Holistic view of Practices in Human living.
Holistic view of Realization in Human being.

modules.module_title: Understanding 'Madhyasth' and Coexistence

content.title: Creative, Destructive, and Madhyasth Powers
content.text: Existence contains creative (sam), destructive (visham), and 'madhyasth' powers. Humankind's unique objective is to establish the madhyasth force, which science has so far failed to understand.
The central theme is that all entities in nature exhibit harmony and participate in the Universal Order, contrasting with theories of struggle.

content.title: Alignment with Science
content.text: Madhyasth Darshan's reasoning aligns science with conscience, where conscience is the acceptance of purposiveness in existence.

modules.module_title: Coexistence, Consciousness, and Wisdom

content.title: The Continuity of Jeevan
content.text: 'Jeevan' can carry forward the results of human effort from one lifetime to the next and has inexhaustible forces and powers.

content.title: Critique of Science's Limitations
content.text: Science alone is incapable of explaining consciousness and existence, leading to ideas of conflict in nature and obsession with profit, sex, and consumption, which do not lead to human fulfillment.
The author's realization is that co-existential harmony in nature is the content of wisdom. Wisdom manifests as resolution in every aspect of human behavior.

modules.module_title: Science, Idealism, and Human Fulfillment

content.title: The Genesis of the Proposal
content.text: The author's discoveries resulted from his focused effort to find answers after being unsatisfied with traditional Vedic knowledge.

content.title: The Potential for Wisdom
content.text: The proposal of wisdom is not limited by the body. Every human being has the potential for wisdom and can be inspired to achieve it.

content.title: Science as a Step
content.text: Science is just one step in humankind's journey towards completeness, which must be acknowledged and appreciated.

modules.module_title: The Chasm Between Idealism and Materialism

content.title: 'Feeling Good' vs. 'Being Good'
content.text: There is a significant gap between 'feeling good' (e.g., drinking cold water) and 'being good' (what is universally beneficial).

content.title: Critique of Scientific Thinking
content.text: Scientific thinking leads to instability by trying to model humans as machines. This creates a chasm between materialism (science) and idealism (feelings, emotions), trapping humankind in problems.

content.title: A Collective Effort
content.text: The author's proposal is presented as the result of humankind's collective effort throughout history, not just his own.

modules.module_title: The Role of Space and the Need for a New 'Shastra'

content.title: The Cognizance of Space
content.text: Human self-awareness begins only after recognizing Space. Understanding existence requires realizing that all units exist in the coexistence of Space; overlooking this leads to problems and misery.

content.title: The Contradiction of Human History
content.text: All historical conflicts, revolts, exploitation, and wars contradict the principle of co-existentialism.

content.title: A Failure of Institutions
content.text: The author notes that the State, religion, and education have failed to explain humanity's purpose. He documented 'shastras' (theses) to describe how the wisdom of coexistence can manifest as an art of living.

modules.module_title: The Three 'Shastras' (Theses)

items.details: Proposed as the path to every human being's happiness.
Argues that satisfaction comes from justice (nyaya) in behavior, based on a universal humane conduct that can act as a constitution for all nations.
Postulates that 'jeevan' is the basis of consciousness, and the body is its vehicle for expression.

modules.module_title: The Three Headings of Co-existentialism

content.title: The Three Pillars of the Author's Philosophy

items.details: All units of nature are mutually complementary and interrelated, inspiring harmonious living.
Human fulfillment is only achieved through harmony in behavior with others, defined by humane conduct.
Spirituality is understood through the pervasive, empty Space in which all units of existence are submerged and coexist.

modules.module_title: The 'Yojanas' (Plans for Implementation)

content.title: From Theory to Practice
content.text: From the author's theories ('darshan', 'vaad', 'shastra'), three practical plans ('yojana') emerged to implement the vision.

items.details: Aims to remove ignorance about the self ('jeevan'), which is the basis of human equality.
Aims to incorporate wisdom into education, with a successful experiment conducted in a school.
Aims to establish a social order centered on resolution rather than on power.

modules.module_title: The Four Orders of Nature and the Path to Wisdom

items.details: Soils, stones, gems, and metals, which already evidence definite conduct.
Trees, plants, and vegetation, which evidence their respective definite conduct.
All sentient beings other than humans, which evidence order according to their essence.
Human beings, who are still awaited to get into the order of existence.

content.title: The Root of Human Misery
content.text: The author identifies the root cause of human misery as the Knowledge Order (humankind) lagging behind and not yet being in a state of order.

modules.module_title: Regulation by 'Sanskar' and Humane Conduct

items.details: Regulated by constitution-inheritance.
Regulated by seed-inheritance.
Regulated by specie-inheritance.
Regulated by sanskar-inheritance.

content.text: Sanskar is defined as the conclusive acceptance of wisdom. It is through sanskar that a human being becomes regulated.

content.title: Humane vs. Nonhuman Conduct
content.text: When a human becomes wise, their living becomes orderly, which is called 'humane' conduct. The absence of this capability is 'nonhuman' conduct.

modules.module_title: Wisdom as a Living Tradition

content.title: The Flow of Wisdom
content.text: Wisdom becomes a living tradition when it is passed from one generation to the next. The content of wisdom remains constant, but its presentation can become more precise over time.

content.title: Why Only Wisdom Can Be a Tradition
content.text: A human is a unit of 'sanskar-inheritance'. Since wrongs are never conclusively acceptable, they cannot become 'sanskar' and cannot be passed down as a living tradition. Only wisdom can.

content.title: Jeevan as the Basis of Equality
content.text: The reference for equality among all humans is 'jeevan', which is equal in all due to its constitutional completeness and inexhaustible powers.

modules.module_title: The Verification and Nature of Wisdom

content.title: How Wisdom is Verified
content.text: Wisdom is verified through one's behavior, work, and the orderliness of one's living.

content.title: The Definiteness of Wisdom
content.text: Jeevan is the definite bearer and carrier of wisdom, so the evidence of wisdom is also definite. The fully developed human brain is the necessary instrument for expressing this wisdom.
The core of understanding existence is to realize it as 'Nature saturated in the Omnipotence,' meaning that nature and the omnipresent reality are eternally intertwined.

modules.module_title: The Purpose of Human Tradition and Failure of 'Isms'

content.title: The Failure of Idealism and Materialism
content.text: Past endeavors of idealism and materialism have failed because they did not understand existence in the form of coexistence, which is the root cause of their inability to establish a living tradition of wisdom.

content.title: The Lack of Justice
content.text: The author notes that humankind has not yet found justice, criticizing the judicial system for passing 'judgment' instead of ensuring 'justice'.

modules.module_title: The Essence of Ethics and Human Uniqueness

content.text: Ethics is defined as devoting one's means of living (body, mind, and wealth) for a universal human purpose, which happens through production/service and in making relationships purposeful.

content.title: Protection Through Righteous Use
content.text: The righteous use of one's means of living ensures their protection. This synergy results in eternal good and is necessary for our awakening.

content.title: The Uniqueness of Being Human
content.text: A human being is the only unit in existence that can become wise. The body is a product of heredity, but 'jeevan' is a constitutionally complete atom. Their union's purpose is to evidence awakening.

modules.module_title: Humane Ethics and the Purpose of Relationships

content.text: Humane ethics is defined as ensuring the righteous use and conservation of one's means of living: body, mind, and wealth.

content.title: The Flow of Values
content.text: Values only flow when one recognizes the purpose in their relationships. For example, the relationship with a mother is based on nurturing, and with a father, on protection. In the absence of this understanding, excesses in relationships are inevitable.

content.title: Critique of State and Religion
content.text: The author argues that both the State and Religion currently seem designed to address criminals rather than guiding normal people. They have failed to show a way of living with wisdom, honesty, and responsibility.

modules.module_title: The Centrality of Wisdom and Justice

content.title: Wisdom as the Foundation for Justice
content.text: Wisdom is fundamental for human awakening. Living with justice—which entails resolution, prosperity, and fearlessness—is only possible if wisdom reaches every human. Justice is the backbone of humanness.

content.title: Inheritance of Wisdom or Illusion
content.text: A human being is a unit of 'sanskar-inheritance', inheriting either wisdom or illusion from their tradition. One becomes wise by imbibing wisdom from their tradition and then applying their own effort.

content.title: Critique of Body-Centric Education
content.text: The author critiques education that has only taught living with reference to the body, leading to obsessions with profit, sex, and consumption.

modules.module_title: The Fundamental Difference Between Humans and Animals

content.title: Key Differences
items: Humans have multi-dimensional expression of jeevan and hope for resolution and prosperity; animals do not.
Humans (in illusion) willfully seek luxury and possession due to a lust for over-consumption; animals do not.

content.title: Jeevan, Illusion, and Rebirth
content.text: The human is the most developed unit in existence. 'Jeevan' uses the body as an instrument but comes into illusion when it identifies with the body, leading to rebirth. This cycle is a matter of wisdom or un-wisdom, not merit or sin.
Each human can live wisely with self-reliance. This living is a combined form of values (mulya), character (charitra), and ethics (naitikta).

modules.module_title: The Path to Universal Good

content.title: The Emptiness of Slogans and False Assurances
content.text: The author argues that iterating slogans like 'good for all' is not enough, and that traditional religious assurances have proven useless.

content.title: The Universal Purpose of Relationships
content.text: Purpose is found in every relationship only upon becoming wise. This universal purpose is to achieve resolution, prosperity, trust, and co-existential harmony.

content.title: Critique of Modern Education's Arrogance
content.text: The present education system is criticized for building up arrogance in its students, who have a false perception of their intelligence.

content.title: The Innate Tendency for Wisdom
content.text: The author states that humans need to 'understand' before they can 'accept'. He saw that every human being has an innate tendency of seeking wisdom, which gave him the confidence to start his 'Jeevan Vidya' movement.

modules.module_title: The Aims of Jeevan and the Levels of Fulfillment

content.title: The Aims of Jeevan and the Human Being

items.details: Happiness, peace, contentment, and bliss.
Resolution, prosperity, fearlessness, and co-existential harmony.

content.title: Interconnection of Aims
content.text: When the aims of the human being are accomplished, the aims of jeevan are also accomplished. For example, Resolution = Happiness.

content.title: The Five Levels of Jeevan's Self-Scrutiny

modules.module_title: 'Svarajya', Justice, and Living in the Present

content.text: Svarajya is defined as the orderly, self-inspired living of humankind. Humane conduct itself is the description of svarajya.

content.title: Recognizing Purpose in the Present
content.text: We cannot live in the eternal presence of existence until we recognize the purpose and meaning in our relationships. Trying to live in past memories or future hopes leads to listless wandering.
Justice is defined as harmony in human relations, which is achieved by recognizing purpose, fulfilling values, and achieving mutual fulfillment.

modules.module_title: Wisdom, Prosperity, and the Nature of Existence

items.details: Food, shelter, and utilities.
Transportation and telecommunication.

content.title: Achieving Prosperity Through Wisdom
content.text: With wisdom, we can definitively know our physical requirements and thus achieve production and experience prosperity. This leads to orderly living.

content.title: The Content of Wisdom
content.text: The content of wisdom that needs to be understood is 'existence', 'jeevan', and 'humane conduct'.

modules.module_title: The Illusion of Exploitation vs. the Truth of Coexistence

content.title: The Hope for Fulfillment
content.text: Human beings move towards evidencing resolution, prosperity, and trust in the hope of fulfillment. Truth is existence itself, which is eternal and in the form of coexistence.

content.title: The Pervasive Illusion of Exploitation
content.text: The author is surprised how humans could imagine happiness through exploiting nature, a belief propagated by nations, religions, and science through slogans like 'Might is Right'.
A developed nation is one that is awakened and aligned to the universal order, whose people are resolved and prosperous, and who live by co-existential harmony.

modules.module_title: The Failure of 'Isms' and the Path Forward

content.title: Critique of Individualism
content.text: Both idealism and materialism result in making human beings individualistic and have failed to provide a formula for a harmonious, undivided society.

content.title: The Second Plan: Humanization of Education
content.text: The author proposes equipping those who are ready to understand now, so they can teach and instill 'sanskar' in children through educational institutions.

modules.module_title: The Five Activities of Jeevan (Part 1)

content.title: The Nature of Jeevan's Activities
content.text: Jeevan's activities are in five parts, each with two conscious activities: 'sthiti' (state of being) and 'gati' (response in mutuality).

content.title: The First Two Activities of Jeevan

items.details: Selection is the activity for 'taste'. The part of jeevan performing this is 'mun'. The author critiques the amassing of possessions to satisfy this taste, as it has not led to fulfillment.
Jeevan analyzes reasons to recognize the purpose of things. The purpose of human life is to evidence resolution, prosperity, trust, and co-existential harmony.

modules.module_title: Humankind's Purpose and the Nemesis of Lust

content.title: Humanity's Wrong Turn
content.text: Although Earth provided conditions conducive to human awakening, humankind instead drifted towards an endless pursuit of luxury and possession.

content.title: The Nemesis of Lust
content.text: This lust is humanity's nemesis because the Earth lacks the resources to fulfill it for everyone. Possessions should instead be devoted to their purpose: nurturing the body and enabling social progress.

content.title: The Aim of Jeevan
content.text: 'Jeevan's' sole aim is to evidence human awakening. Its success is based on the natural expectation that orderly living is every human being's want.

modules.module_title: The Objective of Living and Capabilities from Wisdom

content.title: The Objective of Human Living
content.text: The objective of living is focused on the human desire to live with happiness. The procedure to achieve this is for 'jeevan' to achieve its own objective, which is accomplished through wisdom.

content.title: Evidence of Orderly Living
content.text: A fulfilled 'jeevan' is able to sustain the human aims of resolution, prosperity, trust, and co-existential harmony. This state is the evidence of orderly living. Coexistence itself is order.

modules.module_title: The Nature of Exploration and Coexistence

content.title: Jeevan as the Locus of Understanding
content.text: 'Jeevan' is the entity that understands. It understands the entire existence in the form of coexistence. A human becomes capable of orderly living—which is happiness—only through this co-existential outlook.

content.title: Exploration as an Intrinsic Tendency
content.text: When human living is in disorder (due to illusion), 'jeevan' begins exploring for resolution. This tendency for exploration and harmony is intrinsic to every atom in nature.

content.title: Inseparability from Coexistence
content.text: Human beings are an inseparable part of coexistence. Every attempt to escape it has only led to more misery. Every human has a natural right to seek order.

modules.module_title: The Four Human Activities

content.title: The Four Activities of a Human Being
Humanity's Unique Activities
content.text: While all other orders in nature operate on the basis of 'recognizing and responding', human beings have two additional, unique activities: 'knowing and believing'.

content.title: The Path to Fulfillment
content.text: A human being becomes fulfilled and assured only when their knowing and believing are based on understanding the purpose of everything. Without this, one cannot become social or evidence co-existential harmony.
